prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 12CO(1-0) and continuum: Haro11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the nearby starburst galaxy Haro11 at band 3 in the continuum and emission line of 12CO(1-0). The other basebands are chosen to detect the continuum. As the source is compact, a single pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the CO(1-0) line at 115 GHz and the continuum in band 3 in configuration C32-5.
Imaging requirements: A single pointing is sufficient since the galaxy (10'') falls within the field-of-view (FOV) of 55'' (similar FOV as Herschel/PACS). From IR observations, we know that the emission from the cold material is compact and we expect to find the molecular clouds confined to the 3 main star-forming knots of Haro11. These knots have typical sizes of 1'' and are separated by about 3''. Thus, the largest angular scale of interest to trace the cold emission is 3''. We choose an angular resolution of 1'', which is well suited for our objectives as it is able to separate the different star-forming clusters while most of the CO flux from each complex will fall within one resolution element, therefore optimizing the signal-to-noise.
Correlator setup: We select dual polarization and 4 spectral windows: 1 on the CO(1-0) line and the others at different frequencies to probe the continuum in the band. We choose a bandwidth of 1875 MHz to have enough velocity range for continuum measurements, with element resolution of 976 kHz (2.6 km/s). The expected line width is about 50 km/s and we can rebin the data to a velocity resolution of 5 km/s if necessary. We will make use of the velocity information to separate clumps along the line of sight and/or analyze kinematics in the molecular gas.
Sensitivity requirements: We have estimated a peak flux density of 12 mJy/beam (details in the science justification). We aim for a 10-sigma peak detection (which allows for some margin if the total line intensity is not distributed evenly over the 3 regions), and therefore expect an rms of 1.2 mJy per beam. The setups for band 3 will also allow us to obtain a continuum measurement (>20-sigma) at the same angular resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 13CO(2-1): Haro11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the nearby starburst galaxy Haro11 at band 6 in the 13CO(2-1) emission line. As the source is compact, a single pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the continuum and the 13CO(2-1) line at 220 GHz in band 6 in configuration C32-3.
Imaging requirements: A single pointing is sufficient to cover the galaxy. We choose an angular resolution of 1'' to match the desired resolution of the 12CO(2-1) science goal.
Correlator setup: We select the line spectral type, with dual polarization, with bandwidth of 1875 MHz to have enough velocity range for continuum measurements, and velocity resolution (1.36 km/s). The line width being ~30 km/s, we can also rebin the data to 5 km/s. Given the redshift of Haro11, the local oscillator cannot be placed to cover both 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously, and we require two separate science goals for band 6.
Sensitivity requirements: We require an rms of 0.8 mJy (details in the science justification) to detect the 13CO(2-1) line at a 5-sigma level (>20-sigma for the continuum). We expect the emission to be clumpy and thus will not miss any extended emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 12CO(2-1) and continuum: Haro11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the nearby starburst galaxy Haro11 at band 6 in the continuum and 12CO(2-1) emission line. As the source is compact, a single pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the continuum and the CO(2-1) line at 230 GHz in band 6 in configuration C32-3.
Imaging requirements: A single pointing is sufficient to cover the galaxy. We choose an angular resolution of 1'' to match the desired resolution at 115 GHz in band 3.
Correlator setup: We select the line spectral type, with dual polarization, with bandwidth of 1875 MHz to have enough velocity range for continuum measurements, and velocity resolution (0.65 km/s). The line width being 50 km/s, we can also rebin the data to 5 km/s. Given the redshift of Haro11, the local oscillator cannot be placed to cover both 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously, and we require two separate science goals for band 6.
Sensitivity requirements: We require an rms of 8.0 mJy (details in the science justification), and propose a short integration that will give us a high signal-to-noise (10-sigma for the line and >20-sigma for the dust) map. We expect the emission to be clumpy and thus will not miss any extended emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 12CO(3-2) and continuum: Haro11
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the nearby starburst galaxy Haro11 at band 7 in the continuum and 12CO(3-2) emission line. As the source of emission is expected within 8'', a mini-map of 3 pointings centered on each star-forming cluster is preferable to a single pointing.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the continuum and the CO(3-2) line at 345 GHz in band 7 in configuration C32-2.
Imaging requirements: The FOV is 18'', the size of the galaxy ~10'', and the emission from the star-forming regions is expected within ~8''. To achieve a uniform sensitivity across those regions, we opt for a small and extremely time efficient mosaic with 3 pointings centered on each star-forming cluster and separated by 1/4 FWHM. We choose an angular resolution of 1'' to match the desired resolution at 115 GHz in band 3.
Correlator setup: We select the line spectral type, with dual polarization, with bandwidth of 1875 MHz to have enough velocity range for continuum measurements, and velocity resolution (0.86 km/s). The line width being 50 km/s, we can also rebin the data to 5 km/s.
Sensitivity requirements: We require an rms of 6.5 mJy (details in the science justification), and propose a short integration that will give us a high signal-to-noise (10-sigma for the line and >20-sigma for the dust) map. We expect the emission to be clumpy and thus will not miss any extended emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This proposal is designed to address two major issues in understanding the ISM properties of low-metallicity starburst galaxies: (1) the presence of a submillimeter emission excess, the origin of which still remains unknown; (2) the difficulty to measure the molecular gas reservoir, as CO is more prone to photodissociation by hard radiation fields than H2. We propose band 3, 6, and 7 observations of the continuum and CO lines to resolve, at 1'' , the cold ISM of the low-metallicity starburst Haro11. With vigorous star formation, bright far-infrared lines (including [CII]157um from our Herschel survey), Haro11 shows a prominent submillimeter excess, and little HI and CO, therefore standing as an outlier from the Schmidt-Kennicutt law. It is the best local case study to look into the low-metallicity ISM under extreme conditions, serving as a template for high-redshift galaxies. The continuum data will localize the component which gives rise to the excess and place constraints on its origin. The line data will enable us to probe spatially the CO excitation and physical conditions (densities, filling factors, etc.), and to determine, with C+, the total molecular gas reservoir.
